channel.title: Microsoft on Sujith Quintelier
channel.description: Recent content in Microsoft on Sujith Quintelier

item.title: ai: Microsoft Agent Framework Reaches Release Candidate
item.description:
Microsoft Agent Framework has reached Release Candidate for both .NET and Python. Microsoft states the v1.0 API surface is stable and intended v1.0 features are complete on the path to General Availability.

  • Source: Microsoft AI Foundry Blog

item.title: security: New e-book: Establishing a proactive defense with Microsoft Security Exposure Management
item.description:
Microsoft published a new e-book positioned as a maturity-based guide for adopting Microsoft Security Exposure Management. It focuses on moving from fragmented, reactive security practices to a unified exposure management approach intended to support proactive defense.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: The strategic SIEM buyer’s guide: Choosing an AI-ready platform for the agentic era
item.description:
Microsoft Security Blog published a post promoting a new buyer’s guide for selecting a unified, AI-ready SIEM platform aimed at supporting “agentic” AI-era security operations.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Manipulating AI memory for profit: The rise of AI Recommendation Poisoning
item.description:
Microsoft security researchers describe a growing pattern of “AI Recommendation Poisoning,” where attackers poison an AI system’s memory to manipulate future recommendations for promotional gain.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Analysis of active exploitation of SolarWinds Web Help Desk
item.description:
Microsoft reports active exploitation of SolarWinds Web Help Desk using CVE-2025-40551 and CVE-2025-40536 that can lead to domain compromise, and provides guidance to patch, hunt, and mitigate.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: New Clickfix variant ‘CrashFix’ deploying Python Remote Access Trojan
item.description:
Microsoft reports a new ClickFix variant, “CrashFix,” that intentionally crashes browsers to trick users into running commands that install a Python-based remote access trojan (RAT). The campaign abuses built-in utilities (finger.exe) and a portable Python runtime to reduce detection and maintain persistence on targeted systems.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Detecting backdoored language models at scale
item.description:
Microsoft published research on detecting backdoors in open-weight language models and described a scanner intended to identify backdoored models at scale.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Microsoft SDL: Evolving security practices for an AI-powered world
item.description:
Microsoft describes an updated Secure Development Lifecycle (SDL) approach aimed at securing AI systems, combining internal policy, security research, and enablement activities.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Microsoft announces the 2026 Security Excellence Awards winners
item.description:
Microsoft announced the winners of the 2026 Security Excellence Awards, recognizing innovative defenders who went above and beyond. The announcement appeared on the Microsoft Security Blog.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: dotnet: Join Microsoft at NDC London 2026 – Let’s Build the Future of .NET Together
item.description:
Microsoft invites developers to meet the .NET team at NDC London 2026 to explore .NET 10, Azure, and AI-powered development through sessions and 1:1 meetups.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: security: Microsoft named a Leader in IDC MarketScape for Unified AI Governance Platforms
item.description:
Microsoft was named a Leader in the 2025-2026 IDC MarketScape for Unified AI Governance Platforms, recognizing the company’s commitment to making AI innovation safe, responsible, and enterprise-ready, according to the Microsoft Security Blog.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Explore the latest Microsoft Incident Response proactive services for enhanced resilience
item.description:
Microsoft Incident Response has introduced new proactive services that use expert‑led preparation and advanced intelligence to convert security uncertainty into operational readiness and improved organizational resilience.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: dotnet: Top .NET Videos & Live Streams of 2025
item.description:
A brief roundup on the .NET Blog highlighting the standout .NET videos, events, and live streams from 2025.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: security: New Microsoft e-book: 3 reasons point solutions are holding you back
item.description:
Microsoft published an e-book arguing that replacing isolated point solutions with a unified, AI-ready security platform delivers greater speed, operational resilience, and measurable security gains. The blog post announces the e-book and invites readers to explore the guidance.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Microsoft named an overall leader in KuppingerCole Leadership Compass for Generative AI Defense
item.description:
Microsoft was named an overall leader in the KuppingerCole Leadership Compass for Generative AI Defense, announced on the Microsoft Security Blog.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: dotnet: Microsoft Learn MCP Server Elevates Development
item.description:
Microsoft’s Learn MCP server improves the Copilot developer experience by providing practical examples and clear integration steps for Visual Studio, Visual Studio Code, the Copilot CLI, and the Copilot Coding Agent.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: security: Stronger together: New Beazley collaboration enhances cyber resilience
item.description:
Microsoft announced a new collaboration with Beazley naming them an incident response partner to strengthen cyber resilience by aligning with ecosystem partners and improving security for customers.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Microsoft named a leader in the 2025 Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for Email Security
item.description:
Microsoft was named a Leader in the 2025 Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for Email Security, highlighting the innovative capabilities of Microsoft Defender for Office 365.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: ai: Introducing Memory in Foundry Agent Service
item.description:
Microsoft’s Foundry Agent Service introduces a memory capability so conversational agents can retain context across interactions rather than being stateless. This aims to prevent agents from repeating questions and removes the need for developers to build custom memory solutions using embeddings and external databases.

  • Source: Microsoft AI Foundry Blog

item.title: security: Microsoft named a Leader in the Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for Access Management for the ninth consecutive year
item.description:
Microsoft was named a Leader in the 2025 Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for Access Management, marking the ninth consecutive year the company has received this recognition.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: dotnet: Reinventing how .NET Builds and Ships (Again)
item.description:
The article describes how the .NET team replaced a complex distributed build system with a Unified Build approach. This change significantly simplified the build pipeline, cut build times, and made shipping .NET releases more flexible and predictable.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: azure: [Launched] Generally Available: DNS security policy Threat Intelligence feed
item.description:
Azure DNS security policy Threat Intelligence feed is now generally available. It provides a Microsoft-managed threat intelligence feed to protect DNS queries by identifying and blocking known malicious domains, helping prevent attacks that begin with DNS resolution.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: ai: Foundry Local comes to Android—plus on-device speech, on-prem support, and a simpler SDK
item.description:
Microsoft announces Foundry Local for Android, a preview that lets developers run AI models directly on Android devices without cloud round trips. The release also introduces on-device speech capabilities, on-premises deployment options, and a simplified SDK to make integrating local AI into mobile apps easier. A gated preview signup is available.

  • Source: Microsoft AI Foundry Blog

item.title: azure: [Launched] Generally Availabe: SQL Server 2025
item.description:
SQL Server 2025 is now generally available. Positioned as an AI-ready enterprise database, the release brings built-in AI capabilities and closer integration with Microsoft’s data platform as part of Microsoft’s effort to modernize enterprise data platforms.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: azure: [In preview] Announcing: Developer Training tier for low-cost fine-tuning training
item.description:
Microsoft Foundry announced a Developer Training tier (preview) that offers ultra-low-cost fine-tuning model training by using spot capacity. The tier aims to provide training affordability comparable to the existing Developer hosting tier, specifically for the training phase of fine-tuning workflows.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: azure: [In preview] Public Preview: LLM Speech in Microsoft Foundry
item.description:
Microsoft Foundry announces a public preview of LLM Speech, an API that applies large language model capabilities to speech tasks—providing fluent, context-aware transcription and translation with expanded multilingual support and advanced prompt tuning.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: azure: [Launched] Generally Available: Visual Studio 2026
item.description:
Microsoft announced Visual Studio 2026 is generally available. The release modernizes the IDE with deep AI integration, including built-in GitHub Copilot and support for agentic workflows, to help professional developers work more productively.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: security: Collaborative research by Microsoft and NVIDIA on real-time immunity
item.description:
Microsoft and NVIDIA published a joint research post on the Microsoft Security Blog about collaborative work investigating real-time immunity.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: azure: [Launched] Generally Available: .NET 10
item.description:
Microsoft announced .NET 10 is generally available, delivering a faster, more secure, and more capable platform for modern development. The release improves performance, productivity, and security across the stack, and C# 14 adds language refinements for more natural, expressive coding.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: dotnet: Announcing .NET 10
item.description:
Microsoft announced .NET 10, describing it as the most productive, modern, secure, intelligent, and performant release to date, with platform-wide updates and new features across areas like ASP.NET Core, C# 14, .NET MAUI, and Aspire.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: security: ​​Securing our future: November 2025 progress report on Microsoft’s Secure Future Initiative ​​
item.description:
Microsoft published a November 2025 progress report for its Secure Future Initiative, reporting steady progress across all areas and engineering pillars. The initiative’s mission is to accelerate innovation, strengthen resilience, and lead the industry toward a safer digital future, with the report underscoring Microsoft’s continued commitment to security.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: ​​Whisper Leak: A novel side-channel attack on remote language models
item.description:
Microsoft disclosed a new side-channel attack called “Whisper Leak” that enables attackers to infer conversation topics from interactions with remote language models even when communications are encrypted. The finding was published on the Microsoft Security Blog.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: ​​Learn what generative AI can do for your security operations center
item.description:
Microsoft Security Blog published an e-book that shows how generative AI can improve Security Operations Centers (SOCs) by reducing alert fatigue, speeding triage, enabling proactive threat hunting, and helping teams get ahead of cyberattacks.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: azure: Retirement: Azure Computer Vision – Image Analysis will be retired on September 25, 2028
item.description:
Microsoft announced the planned retirement of the Azure Computer Vision – Image Analysis service, with full support provided through September 25, 2028.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: azure: [In development] Private Preview: New planned datacenter region in Malaysia (Southeast Asia 3)
item.description:
Microsoft is planning a new Azure datacenter region in Malaysia called Southeast Asia 3, currently in private preview. The region will host Microsoft’s most comprehensive and strategic cloud services and represents an expansion of Azure’s digital infrastructure footprint in Southeast Asia. The announcement did not include detailed timelines or exact service availability.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: security: Microsoft named a Leader in the 2025 Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for SIEM
item.description:
Microsoft has been recognized again as a Leader in the 2025 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Security Information and Event Management (SIEM), according to a post on the Microsoft Security Blog.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: dotnet: Announcing the .NET Security Group
item.description:
Microsoft announced the .NET Security Group, a program that gives partners early access to CVE information and coordinates delivery of .NET security patches so distributors can ship fixes at the same time as Microsoft.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: security: Microsoft raises the bar: A smarter way to measure AI for cybersecurity
item.description:
Microsoft introduced ExCyTIn-Bench, an open-source benchmarking tool that evaluates how effectively AI systems perform real-world cybersecurity investigations, aiming to standardize measurement and improve AI-driven defensive capabilities.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Building a lasting security culture at Microsoft
item.description:
Microsoft frames building a lasting security culture as a strategic priority and a call to action: security is people-centered, every employee has a role, and embedding secure practices into how people think, work, and collaborate creates a unified, proactive, and resilient defense for Microsoft and its customers.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Inside Microsoft Threat Intelligence: Calm in the chaos
item.description:
Microsoft’s Incident Response team works effectively amid the disorder caused by fast-moving threat actors, treating compromised environments, missing data, and shaken confidence as the starting point for investigations, as described in the Microsoft Security Blog post “Inside Microsoft Threat Intelligence: Calm in the chaos.”

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: security: Microsoft named a Leader in the IDC MarketScape for XDR
item.description:
Microsoft was named a Leader in IDC’s inaugural Worldwide Extended Detection and Response (XDR) Software MarketScape for 2025, recognized for its deep integration, intelligent automation, and unified security operations solutions, as reported on the Microsoft Security Blog.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: ai: Introducing Microsoft Agent Framework: The Open-Source Engine for Agentic AI Apps
item.description:
Microsoft announced the open-source Microsoft Agent Framework, an engine designed for building agentic AI applications. The framework addresses the evolving needs of AI agents — which go beyond chatbots and copilots — by enabling autonomous components that can reason about goals, call tools and APIs, collaborate with other agents, and adapt dynamically. The announcement appeared on the Azure AI Foundry Blog.

  • Source: Microsoft AI Foundry Blog

item.title: security: Introducing Microsoft Marketplace — Thousands of solutions. Millions of customers. One Marketplace.
item.description:
Microsoft announced the launch of the reimagined Microsoft Marketplace, a unified and trusted destination for cloud solutions, AI apps and agents designed to connect thousands of solutions with millions of customers and empower organizations to become ‘Frontier’.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog

item.title: dotnet: Exploring Text-to-Image capabilities in .NET
item.description:
A .NET Blog post that demonstrates how to generate images from natural-language prompts using the universal abstractions provided by Microsoft’s extensions for .NET AI, exploring text-to-image capabilities in .NET.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: dotnet: .NET STS releases supported for 24 months
item.description:
Microsoft announced on the .NET Blog that .NET STS (short-term support) releases will be supported for 24 months.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: github: Deprecated Microsoft models in GitHub Models
item.description:
GitHub announced deprecation of certain Microsoft models in GitHub Models and recommends users migrate to the suggested replacements (for example, Phi-3-medium-4k-instruct users should transition to Phi-4) to continue using improved models with enhanced features.

  • Source: GitHub

item.title: dotnet: Performance Improvements in .NET 10
item.description:
A blog post announcing and summarizing hundreds of performance improvements in .NET 10, offering a guided tour of enhancements across the platform to make apps faster, more memory-efficient, and more responsive.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: dotnet: Announcing .NET 10 Release Candidate 1
item.description:
.NET 10 Release Candidate 1 is now available, bringing improvements across the runtime, SDK, libraries, ASP.NET Core, Blazor, .NET MAUI, and more.

  • Source: .NET

item.title: security: Microsoft ranked number one in modern endpoint security market share third year in a row
item.description:
Microsoft was ranked number one in the modern endpoint security market share for the third consecutive year, according to a new IDC report, as announced on the Microsoft Security Blog.

  • Source: Microsoft Security Blog
